etymology.description: 不(bù) (bù, "not") + 得(得) (dé, "obtain") + 了(了) (liǎo, "end") together convey a sense of reaching an extreme or unbearable point, hence the meanings "terrible," "extremely," or "amazing."
etymology.interpretation: The phrase 不得了 (bùdéliǎo) expresses a strong degree of emphasis, where 不(bù) (bù, "not") combined with 得(得) (dé, "obtain") and 了(了) (liǎo, "end") conveys something that cannot be achieved or ended, highlighting extremity or intensity.

examples.chinese: 他的笑容真是不得了(他的笑容真是不得了)。
examples.pinyin: Tā de xiàoróng zhēn shì bùdéliǎo.

examples.chinese: 暑假到了(暑假到了)，学生们的热情不得了(學生們的熱情不得了)。
examples.pinyin: Shǔjià dào le, xuéshēngmen de rèqíng bùdéliǎo.
examples.english: When summer vacation begins, the students' enthusiasm is incredible.
